spanishExample: ¡Escúchame! Quiero ir.
englishTranslation: Listen to me! I want to go.
vocabIncluded: escúchame: listen to me (Escuchar, imperative contraction)

spanishExample: ¡Escuche! Ella es mayor de lo que usted quiere.
englishTranslation: (Formal) Listen! She is older than what you want.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons
usted: "you", formal subject pronoun, taking 3rd-person treatment

spanishExample: ¡Escuchen! Él no se parece a mí, no es fuerte.
englishTranslation: (Plural) Listen! He doesn’t look like me, he isn’t strong.
vocabIncluded: parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: ¡Oiga! Ese avión es más largo de lo que creía.
englishTranslation: (Formal) Listen! That plane is longer than I thought.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
creía: believed, I believed (Creer, imperfect, 1st person)
de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons

spanishExample: ¡Oigan! Estoy trabajando, así que seré la tercera.
englishTranslation: (Plural) Listen! I’m working, so I’ll be the third one(f).
vocabIncluded: seré: "will be", "I will be" (Ser, future, 1st person)

spanishExample: ¡Oye, trabaja! No es tan difícil.
englishTranslation: Hey, work! It’s not so difficult.
vocabIncluded: tan: "so" as an adverb right before an adjective or adverb

spanishExample: ¡Oye! ¿Has oído el tren?
englishTranslation: Hey! Have you heard the train?
vocabIncluded: has: "have", "you have" before a participle (Haber, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Ella escucha a todos y por eso trabaja aquí.
englishTranslation: She listens to everyone and that’s why she works here.
vocabIncluded: "the personal a": using an extra "a" before a direct object when it's a person
escucha: listens, he/she/it listens (Escuchar, present, 3rd person)
trabaja: works, he/she/it works (Trabajar, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Es fácil trabajar aquí la segunda vez.
englishTranslation: It’s easy to work here the second time.

spanishExample: Escucha, tengo más de diez.
englishTranslation: Listen, I have more than ten.
vocabIncluded: de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons

spanishExample: Hay más de dos aviones en el aire.
englishTranslation: There are more than two planes in the air.
vocabIncluded: de used to mean “than” in numerical comparisons
hay: "there is/are" indicating existence (Haber, present, impersonal)

spanishExample: Lo escuché porque se parece a mí.
englishTranslation: I listened to him because he looks like me.
vocabIncluded: escuché: listened, I listened (Escuchar, preterite, 1st person)
parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Me tiene que escuchar, la película no es buena.
englishTranslation: He has to listen to me, the movie is not good.
vocabIncluded: using Tener with "que" to indicate obligation

spanishExample: Mi coche no se parece a la foto.
englishTranslation: My car doesn’t look like the picture.
vocabIncluded: parece: seems, he/she/it seems (Parecer, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: No quiero que oigan el barco.
englishTranslation: I don’t want them to hear the boat.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
oigan:hear, they hear (Oír, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Nunca oye nada, no sé cómo es posible.
englishTranslation: She never hears anything, I don’t know how it’s possible.
vocabIncluded: cómo: adverb meaning "how?" in a question or implied question
oye: hears, he/she/it hears (Oír, present, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Nunca oyes lo que yo oigo, pero no me importa, quiero que ella lo oiga.
englishTranslation: You never hear what I hear, but I don’t care, I want her to hear it.
vocabIncluded: "lo que": "what" as a connector between phrases
"que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
importa: matters, he/she/it matters (Importar, present, 3rd person)
me: "me" as an indirect object ("to me", "for me")
oiga: hear, I hear (Oír, subjunctive, 1st person)
oigo: hear, I hear(Oír, present, 1st person)
oyes: hear, you hear (Oír, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Oí que ella trabajaba en ese lugar.
englishTranslation: I heard that she was working at that place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
oí: heard, I heard (Oír, preterite, 1st person)
trabajaba: worked, he/she/it worked (Trabajar, imperfect, 3rd person)

spanishExample: Oyó que trabajas en un lugar pequeño.
englishTranslation: She heard that you work in a small place.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
oyó: heard, he/she/it heard (Oír, preterite, 3rd person)
trabajas: work, you work (Trabajar, present, 2nd person)

spanishExample: Quiero que me escuche, esta es la cuarta vez que lo digo.
englishTranslation: I want her to listen to me, this is the fourth time I say it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)

spanishExample: Quizás escuchen, pero no creo que lo hagan.
englishTranslation: Maybe they will listen, but I don’t think they will do it.
vocabIncluded: "que", meaning "that" as a conjunction (even in cases where "that" disappears in English)
creo: believe, I believe (Creer, present, 1st person)
escuchen: listen, they listen (Escuchar, subjunctive, 3rd person plural)

spanishExample: Yo trabajo ahora donde ella trabajaba.
englishTranslation: I work now where she used to work.
vocabIncluded: trabajaba: worked, he/she/it worked (Trabajar, imperfect, 3rd person)
trabajo: work, I work (Trabajar, present, 1st person)
